submitter_user.about: Hi, I'm [Peter Bhat Harkins](https://malaprop.org), a programmer and entrepreneur from Chicago. From June 2014 to winter of 2015 I typically posted a dozen stories per day to [help](https://lobste.rs/s/9pm09z/what_is_on_topic_what_is_not/comments/nie0yn#c_nie0yn) the site reach a critical mass of regular visitors. In October 2017 I became the site administrator after the site creator @jcs stepped down. * Please don’t message me for an invitation if we're complete strangers; check the user list for someone you know or ask [in chat](https://lobste.rs/chat). * Submit a [`meta`](https://lobste.rs/t/meta) post for feature requests (including new tags) to let the community discuss. Bug reports and "is this a bug?" should go to [the issue tracker](https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters/issues). * [Message me](https://lobste.rs/messages?to=pushcx) for administrative and moderator things. I don't see everything and I gotta sleep sometime. * E-mail my first name @malaprop.org regarding site security or if you can't log in to message me. If I've posted or commented about something here or in the chat room, I'd almost certainly love to talk more about it.

title: Application of Operation Research in Software Engineering?
description:
Hi fellow lobsters, I am a first-year Ph.D. student in Operation Research looking for research topics. I am always interested in building software, so I would like to work in the context of software engineering. As experienced programmers, can you share some open problems in software that can potentially be tackled by tools from Operation Research?

For example, OS kernels have to make a lot of decisions, e.g. which thread to switch to when CPUs are overloaded, which page to evict when memory is running low, and which process to kill when the OOM. Do we have a theory for these decisions, or are they just heuristic-based? In the latter case, can we achieve better performance/fairness by implementing some data-driven decision-making or stochastic control algorithms with eBPF? On the application level, I’m thinking about SQL databases, whose interaction with the network or filesystem could probably use some optimization from queuing theory, but maybe that has already been done.

My ultimate goal is to make some practical algorithms or software packages that people can use, rather than doing theoretical analysis. Please tell me where can I make a difference!
description_plain:
Hi fellow lobsters, I am a first-year Ph.D. student in Operation Research looking for research topics. I am always interested in building software, so I would like to work in the context of software engineering. As experienced programmers, can you share some open problems in software that can potentially be tackled by tools from Operation Research?

For example, OS kernels have to make a lot of decisions, e.g. which thread to switch to when CPUs are overloaded, which page to evict when memory is running low, and which process to kill when the OOM. Do we have a theory for these decisions, or are they just heuristic-based? In the latter case, can we achieve better performance/fairness by implementing some data-driven decision-making or stochastic control algorithms with [eBPF](https://lwn.net/Articles/941614/)? On the application level, I'm thinking about SQL databases, whose interaction with the network or filesystem could probably use some optimization from queuing theory, but maybe that has already been done.

My ultimate goal is to make some practical algorithms or software packages that people can use, rather than doing theoretical analysis. Please tell me where can I make a difference!
